titleStmt.title: A machine-readable version of Marston, John, 1575?-1634 : : Iacke Drums entertainment (1601)

publicationStmt.publisher: John Marston, 1575?-1634 (1576-1634) Iacke Drums Entertainment: Or The Comedie of Pasquill and Katherine. As it hath bene sundry times plaide by the Children of Powles London Printed for Richard Oliue [etc.] 1601

sourceDesc.p: STC7243 (1601), LION text, checked against EEBO page images of this edition

Play details
Iacke Drums entertainment. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1601. Date first performed: 1600.

encodingDesc.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Iacke Drum Timothy Twedle Sir Edward Fortune Mamon, the Usurer Foole Katherine Camelia Flawne, Page Winifrede, maid Brabant, Snr. Planet Puffe Page1 and various John Ellis Brabant Iunior Mounsieur fo*de*King Pasquil Tyer-man Child A Morrice singer
Country Maid Page2 Mistress Brabant joint speakers unknown speaker

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

sp.p: In good faith Gentlemen, I think we shall be forced to give you right Iohn Drums entertainment, for he that composed the Book, we should present, hath done us very vehement wrong, he hath snatched it from us, upon the very instance of entrance, and with violence keeps the boys from coming on the Stage. so God help me, if we wrong your delights, it is infinitely against our endeavours, unless we should make a tumult in the Tiring house.

sp.l: You much mistake his Action Tyer man,
His violence proceeds not from a mind
that grudgeth pleasure to this generous presence,
But doth protest all due respect and love
unto this choice selected influence.
He vows, if he could draw the music from the Spheres
To entertain this presence with delight,
Or could distill the quintessence of heaven
In rare composed Scenes, and sprinkle them
Among your ears, his industry should sweat
to sweeten your delights: but he was loath,
Wanting a Prologue, and ourselves not perfect,
To rush upon your eyes without respect:
Yet if you will pardon his defects and ours,
He will give us passage, and your pleasing scenes,
And vows not to torment your listening ears
With moldy fopperies of stale Poetry,
Unpossible dry musty Fictions:
And for our parts to gratify your favour,
We will study till our cheeks look wan with care,
That you our pleasures, we your loves may share.

div1.stage: Enter Iacke Drum and Timothy Twedle with a Taber and a Pipe.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Come Timothy Twedle tickle thy Pipe on the green, as I have tippled the Pot in the Seller, and the hey for the honour of High gate, you old Trojan.

sp.speaker: Twedle.
sp.p: And a heigh for the honour of Hygate, Hem, by my holy dam, though I say it, that should not say it, I think I am as perfect in my Pipe, as Officers in poling, Courtiers in flattery, or wenches in falling: Why look you Iacke Drum it is even as natural to me, as bawdry to a Summoner, knavery to a Promoter, or damnation to an Usurer. But is Holloway Morris prancing up the hill?

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Aye, aye ; and Sir Edward and the yellow toothed, sunk eyed, gouty shanked Usurer Maman my young Mistresses and all are coming to the green, lay Cushions, lay the Cushions, ha the wenches

sp.speaker: Twed.
sp.p: The wenches, ha, when I was a young man and could tickle the Minikin, and made them cry thanks sweet Timothy I had the best stroke, the sweetest touch, but now (I may sigh to say it) I am fallen from the Fiddle and betook me to thee.

div1.stage: Enter Sir Edward Fortune, M.Mamon, Camelia, Katherine, and Winifride, Camelias maide.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Sit Master. Mamon ha here is a goodly day nigh.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: I thank you Sir, and faith what news at court?

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: What news at court? ha, ha, now Iesu God,
Fetch me some Burdeux wine, what news at court?
Reprobate fashion, when each ragged clout,
Each Cobblers spawn, and yeasty bowsing bench,
Reeks in the face of sacred majesty
His stinking breath of censure, Out upon it ,

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Why by this Burdeux juice, it is now become
The showing horn of Bezzlers discourse,
The common food of prate: what news at court?
But in these stiff necked times when every Jade
Huffs his upreared crest, the zealous bent
Of Councillors solid cares is trampled on
By every hackneys heels : o I could burst
At the conjectures, fears, preventions
And restless tumbling of our tossed brains :
Ye shall have me an empty cask that is furred
With naught but barmy froth, that never travelled
Beyond the confines of his Mistress lips,
Discourse as confident of peace with Spain
As if the Genius of quick Machiauel
Ushered his speech.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: O forbear, you are too sharpe with me.

sp.speaker: S.Ed.
sp.l: Nay Master. Mamon misinterpret not,
I only burn the bavin heath of youth,
That cannot court the presence of fair time
With aught but with, what news at Court sweet sir?
I had rather that Kemps Morris were their chat,
For of foolish actions, may be they will talk wisely, but of
Wise intendments, most part talk like fools.
The sum is this, bear only this good thought,
The Counsel chamber is the Phoenix nest,
Who wastes itself , to give us peace and rest.

div1.stage: The Taber and Pipe strike vp a Morrice.

sp.l: A Lord, a Lord, a Lord, who

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: O a Morris is come, observe our country sport,
It is Whitson tide, and we must frolic it.
Skip it, and trip it, nimbly, nimbly, tickle it, tickle it, lustily,
Strike up the Tabor, for the wenches favour, tickle it, tickle it, lustily:
Let us be seen, on Hygate Green, to dance for the honour of Holloway
Since we are come hither, let us spare for no leather,
To dance for the honour of Holloway

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: well said my boys, I must have my Lords livery, what is it, a May pole? troth it were a good body for a courtiers imprezza, if it had but this life, Frustra florescit Hold Cousin hold.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Thanks Cousin, when the Lord my Fathers Audit comes, we will repay you again. Your benevolence too sir.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: What a Lords son become a beggar ?

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Why not, when beggars are become Lords sons, come it is but a small trifle.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: O sir, many a small make a great.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: No sir, a few great make a many small, come my Lords, poor and need hath no law.

sp.speaker: S.Ed.
sp.l: Nor necessity no right, Drum down with them into the Cellar, rest content, rest content, one bout more and then away.

sp.speaker: Foole.
sp.l: Speak like a true heart, I kiss thy foot sweet knight.

div1.stage: The Morice sing and daunce, and Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Sir Edward Fortune you keep too great a house,
I am your friend, in hope your son in law,
And from my love I speak, you keep too great a house,
Go too you do, yon same dry throated husks
Will suck you up, and you are ignorant
What frosty fortunes may benumb your age,
Poverty, the Princes frown, a civil war, or ~~.

sp.speaker: S.Ed.
sp.l: Or what? tush, tush, your life hath lost his taste,
O madness still to sweat in hot pursuit
Of cold abhorred sluttish niggardice,
To exile ones fortunes from their native use,
To entertain a present poverty,
A willing want, for Infidel mistrust
Of gracious providence : O Lunacy,
I have two thousand pound a year, and but two Girls,
I owe nothing, live in all men's love,
Why should I now go make myself a slave
Unto the god of fools ; put worst: then here is my rest.
I had rather live rich to die poor, than live poor to die rich.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: O but so great a mass of coin might mount from wholesome thrift, that after your decease your issue might swell out your name with pomp.

sp.speaker: S.Ed.
sp.l: Ha, I was not borne to be my Cradles drudge,
To choke and stifle up my pleasures breath,
To poison with the venomed cares of thrift
My private sweet of life: only to scrape
A heap of muck, to fatten and manure
The barren virtues of my progeny,
And make them sprout, spite of their want of worth:
No, I do love my Girls should wish me live,
Which few do wish that have a greedy Sire :
But still expect and gape with hungry lip,
When he will give up his gouty stewardship.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: You touch the quick of sense, but then I wonder
You not aspire unto the eminence
And height of pleasing life: to Court, to Court,
There burnish, there spread, there stick in pomp
Like a bright Diamond in a Ladies brow,
There plant your fortunes in the flowering spring,
And get the sun before you of respect:
There trench yourself within the peoples love,
And glitter in the eye of glorious grace,
What is wealth without respect and mounted place?

sp.speaker: S.Ed.
sp.l: Worse and worse, I am not yet distraught,
I long not to be squeezed with mine own weight :
Nor hoise up all my sails to catch the wind
Of the drunk reeling Commons: I labour not
To have an awful presence, nor be feared
(Since who is feared, still fears to be so feared )
I care not to be like the Horeb Calf,
One day adored, and next pashed all in pieces :
Nor do I envy Poliphemia puffs,
Swizars slopped greatness : I adore the Sun,
Yet love to live within a temperate zone,
Let who will climb ambitious glibbery rounds,
And lean upon the vulgars rotten love ,
I will not corival him: The Sun will give
As great a shadow to my trunk as his:
And after death like Chessmen having stood
In play for Bishops, some for Knights, and Pawns,
We all together shall be tumbled up, into one bag,
Let hushed calm quiet, rock my life asleep :
And being dead, my own ground press my bones,
Whilst some old Beldam hobbling over my grave,
May mumble thus: Here lies a knight whose money
Was his slave. Now Iack what news ?

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: And please your Worship. the Morris have taken their liquor.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Hath not the liquor taken them?

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Tripped up their heels or so? one of them hath undertaken to dance the Morris from Hygate to Holloway on his heels, with his hands upwards.

sp.speaker: S.Ed.
sp.l: That is nothing hard.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Yes sir, it is easier for him to dance on his head than his heels, for indeed his heels are turned rank rebels, they will not obey, but they are tumbling down the hill apace .

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: And I must after then, farewell my souls delight, Sweet Katherine adieu. Camelia goodnight.

sp.speaker: S.Ed.
sp.l: Nay not to London Sir tonight , i'faith at least stay supper.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Hark you sir, there is but two Lambs, a dozen Capons, half a score couple of Rabbits, three Tarts, and four Tansies, for supper, and therefore I beseech you give him Iacke Drums entertainment: Let the Iebusite depart in peace.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Why Iacke is not that sufficient?

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Aye for any Christian, but for a yawning usurer it is but a bit, a morsel, if you table him, he will devour your whole Lordship, he is a quicksand, a Goodwin, a Gulf, as hungry as the Jaws of a Jail, he will waste more substance then Ireland soldiers : A Die, a Drab, and a paunch swollen Usurer, devour whole Monarchies: Let him pass sweet knight, let him pass.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Peace knave peace.
Daughter, lay your express commandment upon
The stay of master Mamon what it is women's year,
Dian doth rule, and you must domineer.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: No she will not wish my stay, O I am cursed
With her inexorable swiftness, by her love
Which dotes me more than new coined glowing gold,
The utmost bent of my affection
Shoots all my fortunes to obtain her love ,
And yet I cannot praise, but still am loathed.
My presence hated, therefore Mamon down ,
Farewell sir Edward farewell beauties Crown.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Faith as it please you for going, and her for wooing,
I will enforce neither.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: With your pardon sir, I shall sooner hate myself ,
Than love him.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Nay be free my daughters in election,
O, how my soul abhors enforced yokes,
Chiefly in love, where the affections bent:
Should wholly sway the Fathers kind consent.
Fore god when I was bachelor, had a friend,
Nay had my Father wished me to a wife,
That might have liked me, yet their very wish
Made me mistrust my love had not true course,
But had some sway from duty which might hold
For some slight space: but when time shall search
The strength of love, then virtue, and your eye,
Must knit his sinews : I choosed myself a wife
Poor, but of good dissent, and we did live
Till death divorced us, as a man would wish:
I made a woman, now wenches make a man:
Choose one either of valour, wit, honesty, or wealth,
So he be gentle, and you have my heart,
i'faith you have : What, I have land for you both,
You have love for yourselves . Here is Master. Mamon now.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.l: A club fisted Usurer.

sp.speaker: Sir.Ed.
sp.l: A wealthy, careful, thriving Citizen.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Careful, Aye , I, let nothing without good black and white, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.l: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: No sir.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.l: A little back wind, saving your worship. sir.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: I am scoffed at, where is my man there ho?

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: Sir you need not take the pepper in the nose,
Your nose is fiery enough.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: What Flawne what Christopher heart where is the knave become? Hold sirrah carry my cloak.

sp.speaker: Kathe.
sp.l: It seems he can scarce carry himself .

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: He is over the shoes, yet he will hold out water, for I have liquored him soundly.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Why cannot you come where heady liquor is, but you must needs booze ?
What a man may lead a horse to the water, but he will choose to drink.

sp.speaker: Flawn.
sp.l: True, but I am no horse, for I cannot choose but drink.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: A pale weak stripling, yet contend with Ale.

sp.speaker: Flawne.
sp.l: Why the weakest go to the Pot still.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: That Jest shall save him. Sir Edward now good day.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Nay sir, we will bring you a little of the way.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.l: Rely on me Christopher I will be thy staff,
And thy Masters nose shall be thy lantern and candlelight.

div1.stage: Exeunt all. Manent Camelia and Winifride.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.l: Mistress Camelia methinks your eye
Sparkles not spirit as it was wont to do.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: My mind is dull, and yet my thoughts are fixed
Upon a pleasing object, Brabants love.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.l: Indeed young Brabant is a proper man,
And yet his legs are somewhat of the least:
And faith a chitty well complexioned face,
And yet it wants a beard: A good sweet youth,
And yet some say he hath a valiant breath,
Of a good hair, but O, his eyes, his eyes.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: Last day thy praise extolled him to the skies.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Indeed he wares good clothes, and throws his cloak
With good discretion under his left arm,
He curls his boot with judgment, and takes a whiff
With graceful fashion, swears a valorous oath,
But the devil, hath a hateful fault, he is a younger brother.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: A younger brother? O intolerable.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.l: No Mistress, no: but there is Master. Iohn
Master. Iohn Ellis there is a Lad i'faith,
Have for a virtuous honest good youth

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: Tut he is good, because he knows not how to be bad,
Nor wherefore he is good.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.l: I know not, methinks not to be bad, is
good enough in these days.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: Nay he is a fool, a perfect Idiot.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Why all the better. And I will tell you this,
The greatest Lady in the Land affects him,
Nay dotes upon him, Aye , and lies with him.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: What Lady, good sweet Winifride what Lady say? Faith there be some good parts about the fool, which I perceive not, yet an other may: what Lady, good sweet Winifride say quick good wench.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.l: The Lady Fortune

sp.speaker: Camel.
sp.l: Why my name is Fortune too.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.l: Then you must needs favour him,
For Fortune favours fools.

sp.speaker: Camel.
sp.l: O but to hug a fool is odious.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.l: Foul water quencheth fire well enough,
And with more lively pallor, you shall taste
The Juice of pleasures fount at private times:
Pish, by my maiden head, were I to match,
I would elect a wealthy fool before all,
Then may one hurry in her Chariot,
Shine in rich purpled Tissue, have hundred loves,
Rule all, pay all, take all, without check or snib.
When being married to a wise man (O the Lord)
You are made a fool, a Ward, curbed and controlled, and
(O) out upon it.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: Believe me wench, thy words have fired me,
I will lay me down upon a bank of Pinks,
And dream upon it ; Sweet fool, Aye it is most clear,
A foolish bed mate, why he hath no peer.

sp.speaker: Winif.
sp.p: Ha, ha, her love is as uncertain as an Almanac, as unconstant as the fashion, Just like a whiff of Tobacco, no sooner in at the mouth, but out at the nose: I think in my heart I could make her enamoured on Timothy Twedle well he that fees me best, speeds best.
sp.l: For as it pleased my bribed lips to blow,
So turns her feathery fancy too and fro.

div1.stage: Enter Brabant Iunior at one doore, Ned Planet at the other.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Good speed thee my good sweet Planet
How dost thou Chuck?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: How now Brabant where have you lived these three or four days ?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Ho at the glittering Court my Pytheas

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Plague on ye Pytheas what have you done there?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Why lane in my Ladies lap, eat, drink, and sleep.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: So hath thy Ladies Dog done, what art in love With yon Hygate Mammer still?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Still, Aye still, and still, Aye in eternity.

sp.speaker: Plan.
sp.l: It shall be Chronicled next after the death of Banks his Horse, I wonder why thou lovest her?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Love hath no reason.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Then is love a beast.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: O my Camelia is love self .

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: The devil she is: 'Sheart her lips look like a dried Neats tongue: her face as richly yellow, as the skin of a cold Custard, and her mind as settled as the feet of bald pated time.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Plague on your hateful humour, out upon it ,
Why should your stomach be so queasy now,
As to bespawl the pleasures of the world?
Why should you run an Idle counter course
Thwart to the path of fashion? Come your reason?
O you are buried in Philosophy,
And there entombed in supernaturals,
You are dead to native pleasures life.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Let me buss thy cheek sweet Pug, Now I am perfect hate, I loved but three things in the world, Philosophy, Thrift, and myself . Thou hast made me hate Philosophy. A Usurers greasy Codpiece made me loath Thrift: but if all the Brewers Jades in the town can drug me from love of myself , they shall do more than ever the seven wise men of Greece could: Come, come, now I will be as sociable as Timon of Athens

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Along with me then, you drumming Sagbut
I will bring thee to a Crewe.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Of Fools wilt not?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Faith if you have any weight of judgment, you may easily sound what depth of wits they draw, there is first my elder brother.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: O the Prince of Fools, unequalled Idiot,
He that makes costly suppers to try wits:
And will not stick to spend some twenty pound
To grope a gull: that same perpetual grin
That leads his Corky Jests to make them sink
Into the ears of his Deriders with his own applause.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Indeed his Jests are like Indian beef, they will not last, and yet he powders them soundly with his own laughter.
Then there is the Goatish French man, Monsieur Iohn fo-de-King knowest thou him?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: O, Aye to a hair, for I knew him when he had never a hair on his head.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: He is a faithful pure Rogue.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Aye, aye , as pure as the gold that hath been seven times tried in the fire.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.p: Then there is Iohn Ellis and profound tongued Master Puff, he that hath a perpetuity of complement, he whose phrases are as neatly decked as my Lord Mayors Henchmen, he whose throat squeaks like a treble Organ, and speaks as small and shrill, as the Irish men cry Pip, fine Pip.

And when his period comes not roundly off, takes toll of the tenth hair of his Bourbon lock : as thus. Sweet Sir, repute me as a ( Puff ) selected spirit borne to be the admirer, of your never enough admired ( Puff ) .

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: O we shall be overwhelmed with an inundation of laughter. Come, where are they?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Here at this Tavern.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: In, in, in, in, I long to burst my sides and tire my spleen with laughter.

div1.stage: Enter two Pages, the one laughing, the other crying.

sp.speaker: Page.1.
sp.l: Why dost thou cry ?
Why dost thou laugh?
I laugh to see thee cry.
And I cry to see thee laugh.
Peace be to us. Here is our Masters.

div1.stage: Enter Brabant Signior, Planet, Brabant Iunior, Iohn Ellis, M. Puffe, and Mounsieur Iohn fo de King.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.p: You shall see his humour, I pray you be familiar with this Gentleman master Puff he is a man of a well grown spirit, richly worth your ~~ I assure you, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Sir I enrol you in the Legend of my ( Puff ) intimates, I shall be infinitely proud if you will deign to value me worthy the embracement of your ( Puff ) better affection.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Speak you from your thought sir?

sp.speaker: Puffe.
sp.p: Aye , or would my silk stock should lose his gloss else, I shall triumph as much in the purchase of your ( Puff ) love, as if I had obtained the great Elixar Let us incorporate our affections I pray you: let me be forward in your favour.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Sir, I pray you let me beg you for a Fool.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.l: I affect no rudeness gentlemen, the heavens stand
Propitious to your fair designs :
As soon as next the sun shall gin to shine,
I will salute the eyes of Katherine

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.l: Of Katherine Master. Planet observe the next,
Master. Iohn what makes you so melancholy?

sp.speaker: Ellis.
sp.l: I do not use to answer questions.

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: What are you thinking on now?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.l: I do not use to think.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.l: He looks as demurely as if he were asking his Father blessing.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.l: I do not use to ask my Father blessing.

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: Heart, how chance he is out of his similes ?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: I have followed Ordinaries this twelve month, only to find a Fool that had lands, or a fellow that would talk treason, that I might beg him. Iohn, be my Ward Iohn, faith I will give thee two coats a year and be my Fool.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.p: He shall be your Fool, and you shall be his Cox come. Ha, ha, I have a simple wit, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I shall crow over him then.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.l: Is there not one Master. Iohn Ellis here?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: There sits the thing so called.

sp.speaker: Br.Sig.
sp.p: Now to the last course: Monsieur Iohn fo-de-King I will help you to a wench Monsieur

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: No point a burn child fear the fire.

sp.speaker: Ellis.
sp.p: As a hungry dog waiteth for a mutton bone, or as a tattered foot boy for a cast suit, even so will I attend on my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: O my Vinifride pree you awe, by gor, me ang the for her.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.l: Nay stay, stay, I will help you to a delicate plump lipped wench.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Toh, phi, phi, your proffer ware stink: stay Vinifride or by gor die, me die, me die by gor, me ang so desirous adiew goot Sir.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.p: O stay Monsieur how do you pronounce Demurra? Ha, ha. I will plague him.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Grand Sot, my vench is gone, and me brule, and me brule, like one mad bule, me go into the water to cool my rein, ang my back made the water hize again, dus so brule, me burst for a wench, and yet grand pock on you all, pray you adieu.

sp.speaker: Ellis.
sp.p: As the Jig is called for when the Play is done, even so let Monsieur go.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Hee, me teach you much French for this, I go to Hygate adieu grand Sors.

sp.speaker: Ellis.
sp.p: As sore eyes cannot endure the Sun, nor scabbed hands abide salt water, so must I leave all, and see my mistress, and as fair Ladies do use foul foils, even so do I bid you farewell.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.p: Why this is sport imperial, by my Gentry, I would spend forty Crowns, for such an other feast of fools. Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: I wonder who would be the fool then?

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.p: Why it is the recreation of my Intellect, I think I speak as significant, ha, ha, these are my zanies, I fill their paunches, they feed my pleasures, I use them as my fools faith, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: It is a generous honour.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.p: Troth I think you have a good wit, ha? pray you sup with me, I love good wits, because mine own is not unfortunate : pray you sup with me.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: I will give God thanks sir, that hath sent a fool to feed me.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.p: Come along then, ye shall have a Capon, a Tansy, and some kick shows my wits, ha, ha, some toys of my spirit.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: I will eat his meat, and spend his money, that is all the spite I can do him: but if I can get a Patent for concealed Sots, that Daw shall troupe among my Idiots.

div1.stage: Enter M. Puffe with his Page.

sp.speaker: Puffe.
sp.l: Boy what is o'Clock ?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Past three, and a fair morning.

sp.speaker: Puffe.
sp.l: Burns not that light within the sacred shrine? I mean the chamber of bright Katherine

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Aye , should appear by these presence, that it doth.

sp.speaker: Puffe.
sp.l: I wonder that the light is up so soon.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: O Mistress Snuff was weary with sleeping in the Socket, and therefore hath newly put on her stammel petticoat, and taken her pewter state to give light to things are in darkness.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.l: And I know that women of gravity and sweetness are soon up.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: I see that women of levity and lightness, are soon down.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.l: Boy clear thy throat, and mount thy sweetest notes
Upon the bosom of this sleek cheeked air :
That it may gently breathe them in the ear
Of my adored Mistress : Come begin.
Delicious beauty that doth lie
Wrapped in a skin of Ivory,
Lie still, lie still upon thy back,
And Fancy let no sweet dreams Iacke
To tickle her, to tickle her with pleasing thoughts.
But if thy eyes are open full,
Then deign to view an honest gull,
That stands, that stands, expecting still
When that thy Casement open will
And bless his eyes, and bless his eyes, with one kind glance.

div1.stage: The Casement opens, and Katherine appeares.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.l: All happiness and unconceived delight,
Wait on the love of sweet-faced Katherine

sp.speaker: Kathe.
sp.l: Good youth Amen: I do return your wish
With ample interest of beatitude.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.l: I do protest, with ceremonious ( puff ) lips
The purest blood of my affection,
Is even fatally predestinate
To consecrate itself unto your ( puff ) love.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Unto my love ? O sir you bind me to you:
Fair Gentleman I have a thankful heart,
Though not a glorious speech to sweet my thanks.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.l: Reward my love then with your kinder love.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: With my love sir, I relish not your speech.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.l: Aye with your love, in pleasing marriage.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Alas sir, cannot be my loves a man,
Who hardly can requite the dear protests
Of kind affection, which you seem to vow
Unto his fortunes: kind youth, you did wish
All happiness to wait upon my love :
Well he shall know it when we next do meet,
And thank you kindly: now good morrow sweet.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.l: You take my, my, my meaning ( puff ) .

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Nay if he be puffing once, the fire of his wit is out.

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.l: Why she is gone. Heart did I rise for this?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: She cannot endure puffing. O you puffed her away

sp.speaker: Puf.
sp.l: Let us slink along unseen, it is yet scarce day.

div1.stage: Enter Mamon with Flawne, bearing a light before Mamon.

sp.speaker: Flawn.
sp.l: Now methinks I hold the candle to the devil.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Put out the light, the day begins to break.

sp.speaker: Flawn.
sp.l: Would the day and thy neck were broke together.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: O how the gout and love do tire me.

sp.speaker: Flawne.
sp.l: Why sir, love is nothing but the very gout.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: As how Flawne? as how?

sp.speaker: Flawne.
sp.p: Thus sir: Gout and love, both come with Idleness, both incurable, both humorous, only this difference: the Gout causeth a great tumour in a man's legs, and love a great swelling in a woman's belly.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: Why then O Love, O Gout, O gouty Love, how thou torments old Mamon: good morrow to the sweet lipped Katherine, eternal spring unto thy beauties love.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Alas good aged Sir, what make you up ?
In faith I pity you, good soul to bed,
Troth soon you will cry, O God my head, my head.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: No Katherine the wrinkling print of time
Erred, when it sealed my forehead up with age:
I have as warm an arm to entertain
And hug thy presence in a nuptial bed,
As those that have a cheek more lively red:
And though my voice be rude, yet Flawne can sing
Peons of beauty, and of Katherine
List to the Music that corrupts the Gods.
Subverts even Destiny, and thus it shogs.
Chunk, chunk, chunk, chunk, his bags do ring
A merry note with chunks to sing
Those that are far more young and witty,
Are wide from singing such a Ditty
As Chunk, chunk, chunk,
There is Chunk that makes the Lawies prate,
There is Chunk that make a fool of Fate:
There is Chunk, that if you will be his,
Shall make you live in all hearts bliss.
With Chunk, chunk, chunk.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: It is well sung good old man, hence with your gold,
Leave the green fields it is dewy ; you will take cold.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: The Casement is shut, well here I will link and stay,
To see who bears the glory of the day.
Hence, hence, to London, Flawne let me alone.

sp.speaker: Flawne.
sp.p: I can hardly leave him alone, for the Devil and double Ducats, still associate him, but I am gone.

sp.speaker: Pasquil.
sp.l: The glooming morn with shining Arms hath chaste
The silver Ensign of the grim cheeked night,
And forced the sacred troupes of sparkling stars
Into their private Tents, yet calm hushed sleep
Strikes dumb the snoring world: yet frolic youth
That is lately matched unto a well shaped Lass,
Clips his sweet Mistress, with a pleasing arm,
Whilst the great power of Imperious love
Summons my duty to salute the shine
Of my loves beauties. Unequalled Katherine
I bring no Music to prepare thy thoughts
To entertain an amorous discourse:
More Music is in thy name, and sweet dispose,
Than in Apollos Lyre, or Orpheus close.
I will chant thy name, and so enchant each ear,
That Katherinas happy name shall hear.
My Katherine my life, my Katherine

sp.speaker: Kathe.
sp.l: My Ned, my Pasquil, sweet I come, I come,
Even with like swiftness, though not with like heart:
As the fierce Falcon stoops to rising fowl
I hurry to thee: do not go away,
The place is private, and it is yet scarce day.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: O these kind words imparadise my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Ha, ha, young Pasquil, have I found you out?
Is it you must bore my nose, I will bore your heart:
Why this same boy is as bare as naked Truth.
A low ebbed gallant, yet she will match with him:
I will match him, if his skin be poniard proof.
He may scape the force of gold and murder, if not,
As you return sir, I will pepper you.
And art thou come dear heart, first fee be this,
This kind embrace, and next this modest kiss.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: This is no kiss, but an Ambrosian bowl,
The Nectar dew of thy delicious soul :
Let me suck one kiss more, and with a nimble lip,
Nibble upon those Rosie banks, more soft and clear
Than is the Jewelled tip of Venus ear.
O how a kiss inflames a Lovers thought,
With such a fuel let me burn and die,
And like to Hercules so mount the sky.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Come you grow wanton. O you bite my lip.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: In faith you Jest, I did but softly sip
The Roseall Juice of your reviving breath:
Let clumsy judgments, chilblained gouty wits
Bung up their chief content within the whoops
Of a stuffed dry Fat : and repose their hopes
Of happiness, and hearts tranquillity,
Upon increase of dirt : but let me live
Clipped in the cincture of a faithful arm,
Lulled in contented joy, being made divine,
With the most precious love of Katherine

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Let the unsanctified spirit of ambition
Entice the choice of muddy minded Dames
To yoke themselves to swine, and for vain hope
Of gay rich trappings, be still spurred and pricked
With pining discontent for nuptial sweets.
But let me live loved in my husbands eyes,
Whose thoughts with mine, may sweetly sympathise.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: The heavens shall melt, the sun shall cease to shine,
Before I leave the love of Katherine

sp.speaker: Kathe.
sp.l: Nay when heavens melted, and the sun struck dead,
Even then my love shall not be vanquished.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: When I turn fickle, virtue shall be vice.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: When I prove false, Hell shall be Paradise.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: My life shall be maintained by thy kind breath.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Thy love shall be my life, thy hate my death.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: O when I die let me embrace thy waste.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: In death let me be counted thine and chaste.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Heavens grant, being dead my soul may live nigh thee

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: One kiss shall give thee mine eternally.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: In fair exchange vouchsafe my heart to take.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: With all my mind, were this Ned for my sake,
But now no more, bright day maligns our love ,
Farewell, yet stay, but it is no matter too,
My Father knows I think, what must ensue.
Adieu, yet hark, nay faith, adieu, adieu.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Peace to thy passions, till next interview.

div1.stage: Enter Mamon, and Mounsier Iohn fo de King.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Now Monsieur be but confident, and hold
There is the price of blood, this way he comes,
Strike home bold arm, and thou shalt want no crowns.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Fear you noting, when he is die, me bring you word.
He, by gor brave crown, brave money,
Me have here a patent to take up, one, two, threescore
Wench : fine Crown, fine Wench, unreasonably fine,
This money is my bawd. Me send a French crown
To fetch a fine Wench, the French crown fetch the
Fine Wench, the fine Wench take the French crown,
And give me the French pock. Hee, excellent, you see
Me kill a man, you see me hang like the Burgullian
He no poine: He by Gor, me have much wit,
Ang me much bald, and me ang much bald wit.
Here come the Gentleman metre Pasquill.

sp.speaker: Pasquill.
sp.l: Is it possible that sisters should so thwart
In native humours? one is as kind and fair,
As constant, virtuous, and as debonair,
As is the heart of goodness : the other, proud,
Inconstant, fantastic, and as vain in loves ,
As travellers in lies: blessed Katherine
Camelia is not thy sister, if she be,
She is bastard to the sweets that shine in thee.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Boniour Metre Pasquill, sance Ies, t me am hired to kill you, Monsieur Mamon, Messier: Iounck, Iounck, give me money to stab you, but me know there is a God that hate blood, therefore, me no kill, me know there is a vench, that love Crown, therefore me keep the money.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Unhallowed villain, that with gold and blood,
Thinks that almighty love can be withstood.
sp.p: Hold Monsieur, there are more Crowns, only do this, return to Mamon, tell him the deed is done, and bring him hither, that he may vainly triumph in my blood, I have some painting which I found by chance in loose Camelias chamber, with that I will stain my breast, go and return with speed.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Hee, by gor I smell a rat, me fly, me fly, by gor.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Lewd miscreant, that through the throat of hell,
Wouldst mount to heaven, and enjoy love,
Invaluably precious : no rank churl,
Thou wast not made to slaver her fair lips
With thy dead rheumy chops, nor clip her waste,
With thy shrunk bloodless arm, I hear him come.
Now Pasquill feign, O thou eternal light,
Mourn that thy creatures should in blood delight.

div1.stage: He lies downe, and faines himselfe dead.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Now smug faced boy, now nibble on her lips,
Now sip the dew of her delicious breath.
Stink, rot, damn, bake in thy cluttered blood,
Snakes, Toads, and Earwigs, make thy skull their nest,
Engendering dew worms, cling overthwart thy breast.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Hush, hush, leave praying for dead, it is no good
Caluianisme, puritanism. Dissemble, here are company.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.l: Good morrow Sir, who lies there murdered ?

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: O Gentlemen, the kindest virtuous youth
That ever adorned London. Damned thieves
To spoil such hopes: the last words that he spake,
Sticks still within the hollow of mine ear.
Katherine quoth he, hold Master. Mamon dear,
I know not what he meant, but so he said.
If that you pass to Hygate tell the Knight,
Pasquill is sunk into eternal night.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Faith it was a good youth, come Brabant, come a away.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Dead Kate, dead Kate, dead is the boy.
That kept rich Mamon from his joy.

div1.stage: Mamon sings. Lantara, &c. Pasquill riseth, and striketh him.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: O the devil, the ghost of Pasquill, I am dead, if you have any courtesy in you, believe it. I believed you when you feigned, believe me now, for I am almost dead, numbed up with fear, give faith sweet gentle youth.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Old wretch, amend thy thoughts, purge, purge, repent,
I will hide thy ulcer, be but penitent.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Ha, I think it was but his ghost that swept along.

sp.p: Grand sot Mamon, Pho, phy, phy, phy, a foutra pour vos chuck, chunk. Iohn fo-de-King teach you a ding, Iohn fo-de-King grand Sot, Sot, Sot.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Death, plague, and hell, how is cursed Mamon vexed ?
Scourged with the whip of sharpe derision:
I will home, and starve, this cross, this peevish hap,
Strikes dead my spirits like a thunderclap.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Gods precious, I forgot to bring my Page,
To breathe some Ditty in my Mistress ear.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Wouldst have a Ballet to salute her with?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: No, but a Song. How wouldst thou court thy Mistress ?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Why with the world, the flesh and the devil.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Right dog, well thou wilt swear, that I am blessed
Beyond infinity of happiness,
When thou beholdest admired Camelia

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: If God would bless me with three such mistresses, I would give two of them to the devil, that he would take the third.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: O when she clips, and clings about my neck,
And sucks my soul forth with a melting kiss.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Doth she use thee so kindly then, ha?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: O Aye , and calls me dear, dear Brabant and ( O Iesu God)
I cannot express her sweets of entertain,
She will so insinuate with chaste amorous speech,
And play the wanton with such pretty grace,
And vows love to me: O I will make thee mad
To see how gracious Brabant is in her eye.
Here is her window, mark but when I call,
How swift she comes, and with what kind salutes
She welcomes me. What ho Camelia?
Faith you will be taken up, what in bed so late?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: And you take her up Brabant, she will take you down.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Heart they hear not: My Camelia wake?

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.l: What harsh uncivil tongue keeps such a coil ?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Winifride it is I. Tell my sweet Duck I am here,
Now mark Ned Planet, now observe her well.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.l: She wonders at your rudeness that intrudes
Upon the quiet of her mornings rest,
And she is amazed, that with such impudence
You dare presume to intimate some love to her,
As if she knew you more than for a youth,
A younger brother, and a stipendary.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Now mark Ned Planet, now observe her kindness.
Good morrow, Master. Iohn

sp.speaker: Ellis.
sp.p: As the Country maid crieth to her Cow to milk her, or as the Travailer knocketh with his Hostess for a reckoning, even so do I call to thee Mistress.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: Sweet Iohn my Love, here is thy Camelia:
Hold wear this favour, with this kiss upon it.

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: Flesh and blood cannot bear such disgrace.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Help, help, help, help, he boxes me that he doth. Help, help.

div1.stage: Enter Sir Edward, Katherine, Drum, and Twedle.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: What outrage have we here so early up ?
Sir you do wrong the quiet of my house.
i'faith you do, and it is but rudely done,
Go to it is not. Is this a place to brawl ?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: And please thee knight, I will tell thee faith and troth.

sp.speaker: Cawe.
sp.l: What did he strike thee sweet?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Aye in good deed law, and a my conscience, I think he hath made my nose bleed.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.p: And would not you draw your weapon out, and to it lustily, as long as you could stand?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.l: I do not use to draw.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Did he give thee a box on the ear, and wouldst thou take it?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: If he be such a fool to give it me, why should not I be so wise as to take it.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Pure honesty, kind Duck, kiss me sweet Iohn

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: Heart Sir Edward, will you suffer this?
Now on my life she is enamoured on the fools babble.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Go to sir boy forbear, you wrong my love,
And you forget yourself to use such Jests,
Such nasty ribaldry upon my daughter:
I tell you Master. Brabant, doth she love
Any that meriteth the name of man?

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: Why he is no man, but a very ~~

sp.speaker: S.Ed.
sp.l: Well, well, no more; my house, my self, my love ,
Opens their hearts with liberal embrace
To entertain your presence: Aye or any man's
So they will be civil, modest, not profane,
Not like to those that make it their chief grace,
To be quite graceless.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Well said honest knight,
We have had blood enough today already :
Ned Pasquil is slain by bloody murdering Rogues.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Speak softly, God forbid, my daughter hears,
Tell me the circumstance, I pray you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Eternal death unto my happiness,
My Pasquil slain ? O God, O God, O God.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Aye , and I think the Usurer made a Tent
Even of his nose it was so red and near :

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: God for his mercy, what mischance is here ?
A good youth, a virtuous modest youth,
i'faith he was. And I can tell your sir,
My daughter Katherine, where is she now?
Whither is she gone? Drum call her hither straight.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.l: Your Drum will sound a call sir presently.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: And as I told you sir, my daughter Katherine
Affected him right dearly: by my peace of soul,
If he had lived, I could have heartily wished
He had been my son in law, i'faith I could:
But see the will of God. How now Drum
Where is my daughter?

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Sir, she is either invisible, or deaf, for I can neither see her, nor she hear me.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Body, of me, my heart misgives me now,
Look, call, search, run all about.
My daughter gone? Go all and search her out.
Here is Pasquil ha? Is this the man that is dead?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Let me entreat this favour, do not search
Or be inquisitive why I fained :
Repute me worthy your better censure: and thus think
My cause was urgent, the rest lie buried.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Well, I would you had not feigned.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Why would you have had me dead indeed?

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: O no, but I have lost my child I fear,
By your strange faining, she no sooner heard
Thy tidings of your death, but gone she was,
And God knows whither. Ha what news now?

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: It is easier to find wit in balloting, honesty in Brokers, Virginity in Shordich then to hear of my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Broach me a fresh Butt of Canary Sack,
Let us sing, drink, sleep, for that is the best relief :
To drown all care, and overwhelm all grief,
Pour Wine, sound Music, let our bloods not freeze,
Drink Dutch like gallants, let us drink upsy freeze.

div1.stage: Exeunt Sir Edward, Planet, Brabant, Drum & Twedle.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: Servant you will go in too, and stay dinner?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.l: Aye in truth, for as the Itch is augmented
By scratching, so is my love by seeing my mistress.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: How is this, how is this, My Katherin gone hence?
Senses awake, and thou amazed soul
Unwind thyself from out the Labyrinth
Of gaping wonder, and astonishment.
My Katherine departed? how? which way?
Fool, fool, stand not debating, but pursue
Haste to her comfort, for from thee doth spring
(Wretch that thou art) her cause of sorrowing.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, tipsy, tipsy, tipsy, all turned whirligig, Iohn fo-de-king, Drum and Timothy Twedle, are rare fine, have for the heavens, i'faith: Drums Lion drunk, and he dings the pots about, cracks the glasses, swaggers with his own shadow. Honest Timothy is Maudlin drunk, and he weeps for kindness, and kisses the hilts of Iacke Drums Dagger. Monsieurs Goat drunk, and he shrugs, and scrubs, and he is it for a wench. Here they come reeling, I must pack, or we shall swagger, for they having a crack in their heads, and I a fault in my hands, we shall never agree.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: A Serving-man quoth you? Heart, and if I serve any that is flesh and blood, would I might never taste my liquor more: stand bare whilst he makes water, out upon it , I will to Ireland and there I will Tan, ran, ty, ry, dan, Sa, sa, sa, sa: Nay it is the only life.

sp.speaker: Twe.
sp.p: Nay good Thewte heart, good kind Iack stay, if you would love me, as I love you, we would live and die together: and please God, would I were dead, and you are gone. And here is Master. Iohn fo-de-king a very honest man too.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Aye, aye , he is a very good honest man: for there is not a hair betwixt him and heaven.

sp.speaker: Twe.
sp.p: He will live with us now and teach us French.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Aye by my trot, ang you help me to a Vench now, me teach you French. five towsand, towsand year, O your Sack is hot, and make me brule, and brule, and burn, for a (hee) by gor your Sack is hot.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Welcome Basilisco thou wilt carry Ieuell, and knock ones brains out with thy pricking wit. Kiss me sweet wench, kiss me.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Hee my Vinifride, by gor you are come, in the very nick to pleasure me, pray you kiss me, clip me, love me, or by gor me ang die certain.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.l: Out you French Dog, touch my Love, and I will

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Touch her, by gor me touch her, and touch her, and touch her.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: I will touch you, I will slash you, I will Wench ye.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.p: Put up, put up, for the passion of God put up, or if you will needs to it, sheath both your weapons in me first.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.l: Heart touch my love, touch my Winifride

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.p: Hark you Iacke, come to my chamber an hour hence, and you shall have what you will ask, and I can grant.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Why then my choler is down. Iohn fo-de-King Fontra for you.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Fontra for me, futtra, futtra, futtra, fiue towsand futtra's for you.

sp.speaker: Twe.
sp.p: Stay friend Iacke, I will reel along with you, if you will not swagger.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.p: Sweet, sweet Monsieur hang yon slaves, I love you infinitely.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: By gor me teach you French four towsand yeare dan.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.l: Well Monsieur I will give you pleasure.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: But will you presently? quickly, for by gor me am a hot shot.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.p: Aye so they say, I heard you were under the Torrid zone last day.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Pish it is no matter, me am like a Tobacco Pipe, the more me am burn, the cleaner me am.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.p: Well then, two hours hence come to my chamber, and Timothy Twedle shall give you me in a sack.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: In a sack ? Ha very well.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.p: And you shall carry me to my Masters house at Holloway for in the house we cannot be private without suspect. Till then, farewell.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: By my trot unreasonably good, I carry the vench on my back, and the vench carry me on her (hee) fine back, fine Wench, fine Monsieur fine, fine, fine Knight, all fine, unreasonably fine, me sing for joy ; by gor me sing la, liro, liro la, lilo.

div1.stage: Enter Brabant Signior, Brabant Iunior, and Planet.

sp.speaker: Bra Sig.
sp.l: Gentlemen, as ever you loved wench, observe Master. Puff and me.

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: What shall we observe you for?

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.l: O for our complement.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Complement, what is that?

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.p: Complement, is as much as (what call you it) it is derived of the Greek word, a pox on it.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Complement, is as much as what call you it, it is derived of the Greek word, a pox of it.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.p: You shall see Master. Puff and me toss it, i'faith mark with what grace I encounter him.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Heart thy brother is like the Instrument the Merchants sent over to the great Turk : you need not play upon him, he will make music of himself , if he be once set going.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.l: Master. Puff I long to do fair service to your love.

sp.speaker: Puffe.
sp.p: Most accomplished wit, exquisitely accoutred, ( puff ) Judgment, I could wish my ability worthy your service, and my service worthy your ability.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: By the Lord fustian, now I understand it: complement is as much as fustian.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.p: I protest your abilities are infinite, your perfections matchless, your matchless perfection infinite in ability, and your infinite ability, matchless in perfection.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Good again, rejoice Brabant thy brother will not live long, he talks Idly already.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Delicious spirit, disparage not your courtesy, stand not bare to him that was borne to honour you.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.p: Let us press our hairs then, with an uniform consent.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: The pressure of my hairs, or the puncture of my heart, stands at the service of your solid perfections: my life is bound to your love, your love being my life, though my life be not worthy your love, your perfection is the centre to which all the parallels of my affection are drawn : your love my life, your perfection, my affection, being ~~

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Your Ass, my Fool.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Being chained by the mighty couplet of inevitable destiny, who seeth the sun, but he must adore it: who seeth beauty, but he must honour it: who vieweth gold, but he must covet it: then, ( O then) who can behold your sun like beauteous golden beauties, but he must more than adore, much more than honour, and most infinitely love to be out, out, out.

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: Out he is indeed.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: He is at a stand, like a resty Jade, or a Fiddler, when he hath cracked his Minikin.

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: Outrageously addicted to the worthy pursuit of such matchless worth.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.p: Sir, I can rest but truly thankful, for your more than good conceit of my no less than little worth. And now sir for the consequent hours of the day, how stands your intention for employment ?

sp.speaker: Puff.
sp.p: I have taken my leave of Sir Edward, bid adieu to love, my Mistress is gone, my humour is spent, my joys are at an end, and therefore Gentlemen, I leave love, and fall to the ( puff ) Law, I will inter myself in Ploydens Coffin, and take an eternal Conge of the world. And so sweet gallants farewell.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.p: Nay I will follow you to your grave. Gentlemen you will not accompany the coarse?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: No, no, look Ned Brabant, yonder is a pleasing object for thy eyes.

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.p: My Mistress is turned Bucephalus, nobody must ride her but Alexander: nobody kiss her but Iohn Ellis. Now stand and list good Planet.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Come sweetest love, let us give time pleasing wing,
What shall we make some purposes or sing?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.l: I will sing, so you will bear my burthen.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Come lay thy head then in my virgin lap,
And with a soft sleek hand I will clap thy cheek,
And wring thy fingers with an ardent gripe:
I will breathe amours, and even entrance thy spirit,
And sweetly in the shade lie dallying.
Now dally sport and play, This merry month of May,
This is the merry, merry month, Sweet time for dallying:
The Birds sit chirping, chirping, The Doves sit billing, billing,
Phillip is treading, is treading, is treading, is treading, is treading,
All are to pleasures willing.
You that are fair and witty, Observe this easy Ditty,
And leave not Natures Natures bliss ; Do not refuse to kiss.
The Birds sit chirping, chirping, The Doves sit billing, billing,
Phillip is treading, is treading,

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: Death I can holder: Life of love
Amazing beauty, let not me seem rude,
Though thus I seem to square with modesty.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Pray you let me go, for he will begin to square, And even as some do were Muffs for warmth, some for wantonness, some for pride, some for neither, but to hide gouty fingers, so will I get your Fathers consent, and marry you. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: Sir it were good you got a benefice,
Some Eunuched Vicarage, or some Fellowship,
To prop up your weak younger brothership.
Match with your equals, dare not to aspire
My seat of love, iwis Sir, I look higher.

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: Astonishment of Nature, be not proud
Of Fortunes bounties: Brabant is a man,
Though not so clogged with dirt as others are:
I do confess my younger brothership;
Yet therein lay no such disparagement
As your high scorn imputes unto my worth.
Coach Jades and Dogs, are coupled still together,
Only for outward likeness, growth and strength,
But the bright models of eternity,
Are joined together for affection,
Which in the soul is formed. O let this move,
Love should make marriage, and not marriage Love.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Woo her no more Brabant thou wilt make her proud,
You Dutch Ancient why should you look higher?
His birth is as good as yours, and so is his face:
Put off your Iengle, jangles, and be not as fair,
He shall renounce it, fore this Audience,
Put off your clothes, and you are like a Banbery cheese,
Nothing but paring: why should you be proud,
And look on none but Weathercocks forsooth?
O you shall have a thousand pound a year
Bar Lady that is a bumming sound. But hark,
Wilt therefore be a slave, unto a slave,
One that is a bound Rogue unto Ignorance?
Well thou wilt serve to make him jellied broths,
And scratch his head, and may be now and then
He will slaver thee a kiss. Plague on such marriages.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: Rude uncivil Clown.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Tut rail not at me, turn your eye upon the leprosy of your own judgment, loath it, hate it, scorn it, and love this young Gentleman, who is a Fool in nothing but in loving thee: mad in nothing but affecting thee: and cursed in eternity if he marry thee.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Sir you have spoke exceeding pleasingly,
For which I love you, as I love a dull dead eye.
Brabant I do conjure thee Court not me,
Do not presume to love or fancy me.

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: How not presume to love or fancy you?
Heart, I will love you, by this light I will
Whether you will or no, I will love you still.
Spite of your teeth I will your love pursue,
I will by heaven, and so sweet soul adieu.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Farewell, and never view my face again.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Hark you fair Winifride sweet gentle maid,
I have but fained with you all this while,
I dote upon the sweet Camelia
And if your favour will but second me,
I vow when I shall wed Camelia
To endow you with a hundred pound a year,
And what I have shall stand at your command.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.l: Sir I will undertake to forward your fair love,
So you will remember what you here do vow.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: If I forget it, heaven forget me :
Do you but praise me, let not her once know
I love, or do affect her for the world.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.l: Well fear no rubs, farewell fair bounteous Sir.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: It works, it works, magnificent delight,
Laughter, triumph, before ever the Sun go down,
Thy forehead shall be wreathed, with pleasures crown.

div1.stage: Enter Pasquil at one doore, and his Page at the other.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Now my kind Page, canst thou nor hear, nor see,
Which way my Katherine hath bent her steppes?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Sir I can.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: What canst thou my sweet Page?
What canst thou Boy?
O how my soul doth burn in longing hope,
And hangs upon thy lips for pleasing news.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Sir I can tell ye.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: What? O how my heart doth quake and throb with fear.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Sir I can tell you nothing of her in good faith.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: O thou hast tortured me with lingering hope,
Go haste away, fly from the pestilence
Of my contagious grief, it will infect thee boy,
Murder thy youth, and poison thy life's joy.
Run search out Katherine in her eyes dwell
Heavens of joy : but in Pasquil hell.
O thou omnipotent, infinity,
Crack not the sinews of my patience
With racking torment: Insist not thus to scourge
My tender youth with sharpe affliction,
If I do love that glory of thy hand,
That rich Idea of perfection,
With any lustful or profane intent,
Crossed be my love, murdered be all my hopes:
But if with chaste and virtuous arm I clip
The rarest model of thy workmanship,
Be then propitious: eternal light,
And bless my fortunes, maugre hellish spite.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Black sorrow, nurse of plaints, of tears, and groans,
Evaporate my spirit with a sigh,
That it may hurry after his sweet breath,
Who made thee dote on life, now hunt for death.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: What soul is that, that with her tear full eyes
Seems to lament with me in miseries?

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Here seems to be the pressure of his trunk,
Dear earth confirm my doubt, was this the place
Which the fair body of my Pasquil pressed,
When he lay murdered ? See the drooping grass
Hangs down his mourning head, and seems to say
This was the fatal place, where Pasquil lay.
O thou sweet print, stamped by the fairest limbs,
The richest Coffin of the purest foul
That ever pressed the bosom of the earth,
First drink my tears, and next suck up my blood.
Now thou immortal spirit of my love,
Thou precious soul of Pasquil view this knife
Which once thou gavest me, and prepare thy arm
To clip the spirit of thy constant love.
Dear Ned I come, by death I will be thine,
Since life denies it to poor Katherine

div1.stage: She offers to stabbe her selfe.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Hold, hold, thou miracle of constancy,
First let heaven perish, and the crazed world run
Into first Chaos of confusion,
Before such cruel violence be done
To her fair breast, whose fame by virtue won,
Shall honour women whilst there shines a sun.

sp.speaker: Kathe.
sp.l: Thrice sacred spirit, why dost thou forsake
Elizeum pleasures, to withhold the arm
Of wretched Katherine O let me die,
Retire sweet Ghost, do not pollute thy hand
With touch of mortals.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Amazement of thy Sex, Pasquill doth live,
And lives to love thee in eternity.
Be not aghast, recover spirit, ( Sweet )
It is Pasquill speaks, it is Pasquill clips thy waste,
It is Pasquill prints a kiss on thy fair hand.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: What do I dream ? or have I drawn the sluice
Of life up ? and through streams of blood
Unfelt, have set my prisoned soul at large?
Am I in heaven ? or in Pasquills Arms ?
I am in heaven, for my Neds embrace
Is Katherines long wished celestial place.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Divinity of sweetness, I protest,
If these inferior Orbs were rolled up,
And the imperial heaven barred to my view,
It were not so gracious, nor so much desired,
As my dear Katherine is to Pasquills sight.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Heaven of Content, Paphos of my delight.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Mirror of Constancy, life blood of love.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Centre to whom all my affections move.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Renown of Virgins, whose fame shall never fleet.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: O I am mazed with joy, I prithee sweet,
Unfold to me, what sad mischance it was,
Forced thy deaths rumour, and such woes dispersed ?
Sad sorrow past, delights to be rehearsed.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: It will be tedious, but in brief think thus,
Old Mamons malice was the venomed foam,
That poisoned all the sweets of our content.

sp.speaker: Kathe.
sp.l: Alas dear heart, that love should be so crossed.
Now good Ned fetch my gown, it is at yon house,
I would be loath to turn to Hygate thus.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: I am obliged with infinite respect, to do you service.
O power divine, was ever such a love as Katherine
Look Mamon, search Mamon, this way she went,
Put on thy spectacles, this way she went:
Blessed, blessed, blessed, be thy nativity,
Yonder she sits, I will either have her now,
Or none shall ever enjoy her with content.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: How love is impatient, when will Ned return ?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Tut, it is no matter when, look where thy Mamon is.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Good devil, for Gods sake do not vex my sight:
Didst not thou plot the death of my dear love ?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Yes, yes, and would complot ten thousand deaths,
Even damn my soul, for beauteous Katherine
My ship shall kemb the Oceans curled back
To furnish thee with brave Habiliments,
Rucks of rich Pearl, and sparkling Diamonds
Shall fringe thy garments with Embroidery :
Thy head shall blaze as bright with Orient stone,
As did the world being burnt by Phaeton

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: You make me death, for pities sake forbear :
O when will Pasquil come? Good Sir depart.
When wilt return ? I pray you Sir go hence,
And troth, I will not hate you: nay I will speak
Against my heart, and say I loath you not.
You vex my patience, gentle sir forbear,
I beg it on my knee, and with a tear.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Tut will you love me, and detest yon boy?

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Heaven detest me first, and loathe my soul.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Is it your final resolution?

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: God knows it is. So good Sir rest content.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Aye , I will rest, and thou shalt rest thus blurred,
Thus poisoned ; venomed with this oil of Toads :
If Mamon cannot get thee, none shall joy
Which he could not enjoy. I fear no law,
Gold in the firmest conscience makes a flaw.
Rot like to Helen: Spittle hence, adieu,
Let Pasquil boast in your next interview.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Be pitiful and kill me gentle Sir.
Heaven my heart is cracked with misery :
Where shall I hide me? which way shall I cleanse
The eating poison of this venomed oil ?
Poor wretch (alas) see where thy Pasquil comes.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Here love put on your gown. How now? good God,
Heaven give me patience : who hath used thee thus?

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: The devil in the shape of Mamon. Sweet
Touch me not. Pasquil I conjure thee now
By all the power of affection,
By that strict bond of love that links our hearts,
Leave and abandon me eternally.
I merit now no love, yet prithee sweet,
Vouchsafe to give me leave to love thee still.
But I do bind thee by thy sacred vow
Of our once happy, and thrice blessed love,
Follow not Katherine: good Ned do not grieve,
In time just heaven may our woes relieve.

l.foreign: fureus. O dira fata, sua, miseranda, horida
Quis hic Locus? qu Regio?qu Mundi plaga?
Vbi sums? Katherina, Katherina Eheu Katherina

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: My Spectacles will betray me, look Mamon search Mamon hereabouts they fell.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: Welcome Erra Pater you that make Prognostications forever . Where is you Almanac ?

div1.stage: Pulles his Indentures out of Mamons bosome.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Lord bless my Obligations, Lord bless my bonds, Lord bless my Obligations. Alas, alas, alas.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.p: Let me see sir now, when will true valour be at the full? O there is an opposition it is eclipsed, Venus, Aye Venus is mounted. Where is the Goat now? Kembed, fine kembed. O here are Dog days, out Upon it Dog days, Dog days, Dog days, out upon it .

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Alas my Obligations, my Bonds, my Obligations, my Bonds. Alas, alas, alas.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Katherina, Katherina, Ehew Katherina.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.l: Obligations, Obligations: Alas my Obligations, I am undone, undone, undone.

sp.speaker: Flawne.
sp.l: Sir, Sir, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: What sir you for, you Dog, you Hound, you Crust, what is best news with you now? Out alas my Obligations, my Bonds, I am undone, undone.

sp.speaker: Flawne.
sp.p: Sir, the best news is, your ship (the Hope well) hath happed ill, returning from Barbary. It is but sunk, or so, not a scrap of goods saved.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: Villains, Rogues, Jews, Turks, Infidels, my nose will rot off with grief. O the Gout, the Gout, the Gout, I shall run mad, run mad, run mad.

sp.speaker: Flawne.
sp.p: Amen, amen, amen. But there is other news to comfort you withal sir.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: Let us hear them good Flawne. My ship, my bonds, my bonds, my ship, I shall run mad unless thy good news reclaim me. Let us hear thy news.

sp.speaker: Flawne.
sp.p: Your house with all the furniture is burnt, not a rag left, the people stand warming their hands at the fire, and laugh at your misery.

sp.speaker: Mam.
sp.p: I defy heaven, earth and hell, renounce my nose, plague, pestilence, confusion, famine, sword and fire, devour all, devour me, devour Flawne devour all: bonds, house, and ship, ship, house, and bonds, Despair, Damnation, Hell, I come, I come, so room for Mamon room for Usury, room for thirty in the hundred. I come, I come, I come.

sp.speaker: Flawne.
sp.p: Why methinks this is right now, I will even lay him up in Bedlam, commit him to the mercy of the whip, the entertainment of bread and water, and the the sting of a Usurers Conscience forever.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Truly Mistress Winifride as I would be willing to be thankful, and thankful to find you willing to prostrate your fair parts to my pleasure, so I hope you will remember your promise, and promise what you now remember, if you have forgot, I would be glad to put you in mind of it.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.p: Truly friend Iohn as I would be loath to break my promise, so I would be unwilling to keep my word to the dishonesting of my virginity. Marry for a nights lodging or so, I will not be strait laced to my friend. Therefore thus it must be. Tonight I must lie at the Farm at Holloway, thither shall you be conveyed in this Sack, and laid in my chamber, from whence you shall have free access to the pleasures of my private bed.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Well then be constant Winifride and you shall find me faithful Iacke Drum and so taking leave of your lips, I betake me to the tuition of the Sack.

sp.speaker: Twe.
sp.p: Winifride my Mistress Camelia stays for you to attend her to the Green, I must go and clap my Tabers cheeks there, for the heavens i'faith.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.p: Stay a little here, and if Iohn fo-de-king come, give him that Sack. O I could crack my Whale bones, break my Busk, to think what laughter may arise from this.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: By my trot, this love is a most cleanly Gentleman, he is very full of shift, the fine Vench, can invent ten thousand, thousand trick to kiss a men (hee) see by gor she have keep her word, she is in the sack already, hee, brave by gor, my blood does sparkle in my vein for joy. Metre Timotty you must give me that sack there.

sp.speaker: Timo.
sp.l: Owy da Monsieur that is well pronounced is it not?

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Ritt, ritt, ritt, excellan: excellan: adieu Timothy me am almost burst for joy.

sp.speaker: Twe.
sp.p: Well, I know what the Wenches on the green are saying now, as well as if I were in their bellies, when will Timothy come, when will honest Timothy approach, when will good Timothy draw near ? Well Wenches now rejoice, for Timothy Twedle doth come.

div1.stage: Enter Pla. Bra.Sig. and Bra. Iunior.

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: Brother how like you of our modern wits ?
How like you the new Poet Mellidus

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.l: A slight bubbling spirit, a Cork, a Husk.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: How like you Musus fashion in his carriage?

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.l: O filthily, he is as blunt as Pawles

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: What think you of the Lines of Decius?
Writes he not a good cordial sappy style ?

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.l: A surreinde Jaded wit, but he rubs on.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Brabant thou art like a pair of Balance,
Thou weighest all saving thyself.

sp.speaker: Br.Sig.
sp.l: Good faith, troth is, they are all Apes and gulls,
Vile imitating spirits, dry heathy Turfs.

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: Nay brother, now I think your judgment errs.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.p: Err, he cannot err man, for children and fools speak truth always.

div1.stage: Enter Mounsieur with a Sacke, and Iack Drum in it.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.l: See who comes yonder sweating with a pack.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Monsieur what do you bear there ha?

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Pray you away, you break my glasses der, Ieshu, now me know not what to do, Zot that I was to come this way widd dem.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Glasses you salt rheum, come what have you there?

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Trike no more for Ieshu sake, by gor me have brittle vare, if you knock it, it will break present, pre you adieu.

sp.speaker: Br.Iu.
sp.l: We must know what is in the bag i'faith.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: By my trot, me tell you true, will you not trike me then ?

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: No faith, but see you tell us true, or else.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Or else, or else by gor, do what you please with me: Sweet Vinifride my very art dus vurst, he by gor, me did not think to wrong you dus: come out sweet Vinifrid me much discredit you.
sp.l: He Iack Drum Iesu vat made you there ?

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: Gentlemen my Master. desires you to come sup with him, I was sent to invite you, and this itching goat, would needs ease my legs and carry me: I hope you will come, and so I take my leave. Aye , I am gulled, but if I quit her not, well.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.l: Come, there is some knot of knavery in this trick.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: His colour is not currant, well, let pass.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.l: Come Monsieur come, I will help you to a Wench,
Go down the hill before, I will follow you.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Me dank you: Mor deu, he mon a me, me am struck dead wit grief, the cock of my humour is down , and me may hang myself for a Wench.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.l: Gentlemen will you laugh heartily now?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Aye , and if thou wilt play the fool kindly now.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.l: I will strait frame the strongest eternal Jest
That ever was builded by Invention :
My wife lies very private in the Town,
I will bring the French man to her presently,
As to a loose lascivious Courtesan :
Nor he, nor you, nor she, shall know the rest,
But it shall be immortal for a Jest.

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: Farewell brother, we shall meet at Hygate soon.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: The wicked Jest be turned on his own head,
Pray God he may be kindly Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: Carry this favour to my Ellis straight,
I long to see him, prithee bid him come.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.l: I would be loath to nourish your defame,
And therefore Mistress pray you pardon me.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: What is thy judgment of my Ellis changed ?

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.l: No that is firm : but your estate is changed.
You know your sister is strangely vanished,
And now the hope and revenue of all,
Calls you his sole, and fair apparent heir :
Now therefore would I have you change your love.
Indeed I yield it is modern policy,
To kiss even dirt that plasters up our wants.
I will not deny, it is worthy wits applause,
For women on whom lowering Fortune squints,
And casts but half an eye of due respect,
To pin some amorous Idiot to their eyes,
And use him as they use their Looking glass,
See how to adorn their beauties by his wealth,
And then case up the fool and lay him by.
But for such Ladies as yourself is now,
Whose fortunes are sustained by all the props
That gracious Fortune can advance you with,
For such a one to yoke her free sweet youth
Unto a Lown, a Dane like barbarous Sot,
A gilden Truncheon, fie, it is slavish vile.
O what is richer than content in love ?
And will you now having so huge a Ruck
Of heaped up fortunes, go and chain yourself
To a dull post, whose very eyes will blaze
His base bred spirit, where so ever he comes,
And shame you with the very name of wife.
No Mistress, no, I have found out a man
That merits you, if man can merit you.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: Lord what a tide of hate comes creeping on
Upon my former judgment ? Come, the man?

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.l: The man? ( O God) the man is such a man,
That he is matchless : O, I shall profane
His name, with unrespected utterance.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: O thou tormentest me, dear Winifride the man?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: By the sweet pleasures of an amorous bed,
I think you will be deified by him.
O God the most accomplished man that breathes,
And Planet is the man.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: Out on the devil, there is a man indeed.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.l: Nay look you now, you will straight overshoot yourself,
You will say he is sour and unsociable :
Tush you know him not, that humour is forced :
But in his native spirit he is as kind
As is the life of love. And then the clearest skin,
The whitest hand, the cleanest well shaped leg :
The quickest eye: Fie, fie, I shall but blur
And sully his bright worth with my rude speech.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: Well, if he court me, I will not be much coy.

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: Court you? nay you must court him for aught I know:
You must not think forsooth, that I am feed
To urge you thus. I solemnly protest,
I motion this out of my pure vowed love,
Which wisheth all advancement and content
To attend the glory of your beauteous youth.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: O I am Planet stricken Winifride
How shall I intimate my love to him?

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.l: I saw him coming up the hill even now,
Send him a favour, and I will bear it to him,
And tell him you desire to speak with him.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Do, do, dear Winifride sweet wench make haste.

div1.stage: Enter Sir Edward Fortune, and Iohn Ellis, with a Paper in his hand.

sp.speaker: Ellis.
sp.p: Sir, I have her good will, and please you now to give me your consent, and look you Sir, here I have itemmed forth what I am worth.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.p: Tush show me no Items, and she love you, in God name: I will not be cursed by my daughter for forcing her to clip a loathed, abhorred match: and see how fortunate we are; look where she stands.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: Sweet Planet thou only governest me .

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Daughter give me your hand, with your consent, I give you to this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Marry phoh, will you match me to a fool ?

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: God pardon me, not I: why Master. Ellis ha?
Had you her consent, speak freely man?

sp.speaker: El.
sp.l: Indeed law now, I thought so: by my troth
You said you loved me, that you did indeed.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Aye as my fool, my Idiot to make sport.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Fie daughter, you are too plain with him.
Alas my son Simile is out of countenance.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: Truly as a Mill horse, is not a horse Mill, and as a Cart Jade, is not a Jade Cart, even so will I go hang myself .

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.p: Marry god forbid, what frolic, frolic man, we will have a Cup of Sack and Sugar soon, shall quite expel these musty humours of stale melancholy.

div1.stage: Enter Pasquil and a Countrey Wench, with a Basket of Egges.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Is this the Egg where Castor and Pollux bred?
I will crack the Bastard in the very shell.

sp.speaker: Coun.Mayd.
sp.l: Alas my markets, my markets are clean spoiled.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Vbi Hellena, vbi Troia is it not true my Ganimede
When shall old Saturn mount his Throne again ?
See, see, alas how bleak Religion stands.
Katherina, Katherina you damned Titanoies
Why prick you heavens ribs with blasphemy ?
Python yet breathes, old gray haired piety.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Alas kind youth, how came he thus distraught?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: I left him in pursuit of Katherine
And found him in this strange distemperature.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: O Sir, is it you that stamp on literature ?
You are inspired you with Prophecy.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.l: Not I, as I shall be saved, I am Master. Iohn Ellis I.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Come, come, let us entice him by some good means,
I will labour to reclaim him to his wits.
O now my daughter Katherine remembers me,
Where art thou girl ? heaven give me patience.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Poor, poor Astrea who blurs thy orient shine?
Come yonder is the Capital of Jupiter
Let us whip the Senate, else they will not leave
To have their Justice blasted with abuse
Of flattering Sycophants. Come let us mount the Stars,
Reverend antiquity go you in first ~~
Dotage will follow. Then comes pale faced Lust ~~
Next Sodome, then Gomorha, next poor I,
By heaven my heart is burst with misery.

div1.stage: Enter Brabant Signior, Mounsieur and the Page.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: I have tell you the very troth of the lag Jest, by gor your England Damosells are so fear, so witty, so kit, by my troth she toss me wish vey she please der: but pre you where is the Vench? Is this the house? Ha is this the house, pre you tell me ha?

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.l: It is, it is, and she is in the Inner Chamber:
Boy call her forth.
By gor den me must needs now sing,

l.foreign: Ding, ding, a ding, Dinga, dinga, ding,

sp.l: For me am now at pleasures spring.

l.foreign: Dinga, ding, ding, dinga, dinga, dinga, ding,
And a hee da vench, da vench, da vench,
Which must my bruling humor quench. Coma, coma, com.

sp.speaker: Mist.Bra.
sp.l: Now sweet, you kept your promise well last night.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: By gor she give him much kind word already.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
