sp.p: Well to make thee amends, boy fetch us a quart of Canary Sack. Prithee Mall entertain this French Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Mist.Bra.
sp.l: Sir you are very welcome to my Lodging.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Me thank you, and first me kiss your finger, next me buss your lip, and last me clip your waist, and now foutra for the Vinifride

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Sir Edwards Caterer passed by sir, you willed me to remember Lemons.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.p: Gods precious it is true: Boy go with me to Billings gate. Mall I will return straight.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Will you no Vin sir, hee, he is gone purposely, by my troth most kind Gentleman. Fair Madam pray you pity me, by Gor me languish for your love, me am a pouera French Gentleman, pray you show me your bed Chamber.

sp.speaker: Mist.Bra.
sp.l: What mean you sir, by this strange passion?

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Nay noting, by Gor damosell, you be so fair, so admirably fair, flesh and blood cannot endure your countenance, me brule, ang me brule, ang you have no compassion, by gor me ang quite languish. Last night me go to bed, ang me put the candle behind me, and by my troth me see clean through me. Me ang so dry, me put a cold platter at my back, and my back melt the platter quite, do so burn. pray you show me your bed Chamber, me will be secrete constant: I love you unreasonably well, unreasonably well by gor.

sp.speaker: Mist.Bra.
sp.l: In faith you make me blush, what should I say?

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Say no, and take it: Or are you one thing, Say neither yea nor no, but take it, and say nothing.

sp.speaker: Mist.Bra.
sp.l: You will be close and secret?

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.l: Secret, by god as sacred as your soul, me will tell nothing, possible.

sp.speaker: Mist.Bra.
sp.l: Well Sir, if it please you to see my Chamber, it is at your service.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Hee now me ang brave Monsieur, by gor ang me had know this, me wood have eat some Potatoes, or Ringoe: but well : hee. Me will thank Metre Brabant for this, by gor me am caught in heaven bliss.

div1.stage: Enter Camelia and Winifride, hanging on Planets armes.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: O too unkind, why dost thou scorn my love ?
She that with all the vehemence of speech
Hath been pursued, and kneeled too for love,
Prostrates herself, and all her choicest hopes,
As low as to thy feet, disdain me not,
To scorn a Virgin, is man's odious blot.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: To scorn a man, is Virgins odious blot.
Wert thou as rich as is the Oceans womb,
As beauteous as the glorious frame of heaven,
Yet would I loath thee worse than varnished skulls,
Whose rivals are daubed up with plastering paint.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: O Rocky spirit.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Breathe not in vain, I hate thy flatterings,
Detest thy purest elegance of speech,
Worse than I do the Croaking of a Toad.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.l: Sweet Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Peace you Rebato pinner, Potting stick,
You bribed corruptors of affection:
I hate you both, by heaven I hate her more
Than I do love myself. Hence pack, away,
I will sooner dote upon a blear eyed Witch,
A sapless Beldam, than I will flatter thee.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: Be not too cruel sweet Planet dear relent,
Compassionate my amorous languishment.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Ha, ha, I prithee kneel, beg, blubber, Cry,
Whilst I behold thee with a loathing eye:
And laugh to see thee weep.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: Look, on my knees I creep,
Be not impenetrable beauteous youth,
But smile upon me, and I will make the air
Court thy choice ear with soft delicious sounds.
Bring forth the Viols, each one play his part,
Music is the quiver of young Cupids dart.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Out Siren, peace screech owl, hence chattering Pie,
The blacked beaked night Crow, or the howling Dog,
Shall be more gracious than thy squeaking voice:
Go sing to Master. Iohn I shall be blunt
If thou depart not, hence go mourn and die,
I am the scourge of light inconstancy.
Thus my dear Brabant, am I thy revenge,
And whip her for the peevish scorn she bare
To thy weak younger birth: O that the souls of men
Were temperate like mine, then Natures paint
Should not triumph over our infirmities.
I do adore with infinite respect,
Women whose merit issues from their worth
Of inward graces, but these rotten posts
That are but guilt with outward garnishment,
O how my soul abhors them. yonder is my friend,
I will conceal what I for him have wrought,
Nice Jealousy mistakes a friendly part:
Now Brabant where is thy elder brother ha?
What hath he built the Jest with Monsieur yet?

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: Faith I know not, but I heard he left the French man with his wife.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Knew she thy brothers meaning?

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: Not a whit, she is a mere stranger to this merriment.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Hit and be lucky, O that it were lawful now
To pray to God that he were Cuckold.
Dear Brabant I do hate these bombast wits,
That are puffed up with arrogant conceit
Of their own worth, as if Omnipotence
Had hoised them to such unequalled height,
That they surveyed our spirits with an eye
Only create to censure from above,
When good souls they do nothing but reprove.
See where a Shallop comes. How now, what news ?

div1.stage: Enter Winifride, and whispers with Planet.

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: What might this mean, that Winifrid salutes
The blunt tongued Planet with such private speech?
See with what vehemence she seems to urge
Some private matter. Planet is my friend,
And yet the strongest link of friendship is strained,
When female love puts to her mighty strength.
Mark, Mark, she offers him Camelias scarf :
Now on my life it is so: Planet supplants my love.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Friend I must leave thee, prithee pardon me,
We will meet at supper soon with the good knight.

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: Aye, aye , content: hell to my delight,
My friend will murder me, thin Cobweb Lawn
Burst with each little breath of tempting sweets.
She entreats you Master. Planet to meet
Her at the Cross style.

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: Ha, at the cross style, well I will meet him there.
He that is perfidious to me in my love,
Confusion take him, and his blood be spilt
Without confusion to the murderer.

div1.stage: Enter Bra.Iu. and his Page, charging a Pistoll.

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: So load it soundly, murder is great with me,
Go Boy, discharge it, even in Planets breast,
Shoot him quite through, and through, thou canst not sin
To murder him, that murdered his dear friend
With damned breach of friendship, when he is slain
Bring me his Cloak and Hat, here I will stay
To be embraced in steed of Planet go, away.
I had rather die with blood upon my head,
Shame and reproach clogging my heavy hour,
Than to have my friend still wounding of my soul
With reprobate Apostacisme in love.
O this Sophisticate friendship, that dissolves
With every heat of Fancy, let it melt
Even in Hells Forge. Hark, the Pistol is discharged,
The Act of gory murder is performed.
Have mercy heaven : my soul is rent
With Planets wound. Come Boy the Hat and Cloak,
Go post to Scotland there are crowns for thee,
Leave Brabant unto death, and obloquy.
Why now the ulcerous swelling of my hate
Is broken forth: O that these women's beauties,
This Natures witchcraft, should enchant our souls
So infinitely unrecoverable,
That Hell, death, shame, eternal infamy,
Cannot reclaim our desperate resolves,
But we will on spite of damnation.
Come ye poor garments of my murdered friend,
Mourn that you are compelled to hide his limbs
That slew you Master. See Camelia comes,
I will stand thus muffled and deceive her sight,
When love makes head, friendship is put to flight.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: Persist not still, thou relentless youth
To scorn my love : what though I scorned thy friend,
Do not upbraid me still with hating him,
Do not still view me with a loathing eye.
For Brabants sake, do you but love me sweet,
And I will not scorn him. Why shouldest be so nice
In keeping laws of friendship? didst thou ever hear
Of any soul that held a friend more dear,
Than a fair woman?

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: O the sting of death, how hath Brabant erred ?
Hence thou vile womb of my damnation,
O thou wronged spirit of my murdered friend,
Thou guiltless, spotless, pure Immaculate,
Behold this arm thrusting swift vengeance
Into the Trunk of a cursed damned wretch.

sp.speaker: Wini.
sp.l: He will spoil himself , let us run and call for help.

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: Now have I room for murder, this vast place,
Hushed silence, and dumb solitude, are fit
To be observers of my Tragedy.
Planet accept the smoke of reeking blood
To expiate thy murder. Friend I come,
We will troop together to Elizium

div1.stage: Enter Sir Edward, Camelia, Winifride, Ellis, Brabant Sig. Twedle, Drum, and others.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Hold harebrained youth, what mischief mads thy thoughts?

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: Forbear good knight, you never sinned so deep,
As in detaining this just vengeance
To light upon me, but know I will die,
I have infringed the laws of God and Man,
In shedding of my Planets guiltless blood,
Who I supposed corivalled me in love
Of that Camelia but injuriously :
And therefore gentle knight, let mine own hand
Be mine own hangman.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.l: Brother I will get you pardon, fear it not.

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: You will get my pardon, brother pardon me,
You shall not, for I will die in spite of thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: I am turned wild in wonder of this act.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Come Brabant come, give me my Cloak and Hat,
The evening is raw and dank, I shall take cold.
How now? turned mad, why starest thou on me thus?
Give me my Cloak. Heart is the youth distraught?

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: Ha, dost thou breathe, let us see where is thy wound?

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Dost breathe, my wound, what dost thou mean by this?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Gentlemen I can direct you forth
This Labyrinth of intricate misdoubts,
My Master. willed me kill that Gentleman,
Now I thought he was mad in putting me
To such an enterprise, and therefore soothed him up,
With I sir, yes sir, and so sir, at each word,
Whilst he would show me how to hold the Dag,
To draw the Cock, to charge, and set the flint,
Mean time I had the wit to think him mad,
And therefore went, and as he willed me shot,
Which he God knows, thought pierced his dear friends heart,
Then went and borrowed that same Hat and cloak
Of Master. Planet brought them to my Master,
And so.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: No more, no more, knight I will make thee smile
When I discourse how much my friend hath erred.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: I will dissolve and melt my soul tonight ,
In influent laughter. Come my Jocund spirit
Presageth some unhoped for happiness :
We will crown this evening with triumphant joy,
I will sup upon this Green, here is room enough
To draw a liberal breath, and laugh aloud:
Drum fetch the Table: Twedle scour your Pipe,
For my old bones will have a Round tonight .
Now by my troth if I had thought of it too,
I would have had a play: i'faith I would.
I saw the Children of Powles last night,
And troth they pleased me pretty, pretty well,
The Apes in time will do it handsomely.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: i'faith I like the Audience that frequenteth there
With much applause: A man shall not be choked
With the stench of Garlic, nor be pasted
To the barmy Jacket of a Beer brewer.

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: It is a good gentle Audience, and I hope the Boys
will come one day into the Court of requests.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.l: Aye and they had good Plays, but they produce
Such musty fopperies of antiquity,
And do not suit the humorous ages backs
With clothes in fashion.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Well Brabant well, you will be censuring still,
There lies a Jest in steep will whip you for it.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Gallants I have no judgment in these things,
But will it please you sit? Camelia
Call these same Gentlemen unto thee wench:
O there with thee my Katherine was wont
To sit with graceful presence, well let it pass :
Fetch me a Cup of Sack. Come Gallants sit,
Master. Brabant, Master. Planet, I pray you sit.
Young Master. Brabant, and Gods precious Master. Iohn,
Sit all, and consecrate this night to mirth.
Here is old Neds place: Come, sound Music there,
What Gallants have you never a Page can entertain
This pleasing time with some French brawl or Song?
What shall we have a Galliard? troth it is well.
Good Boy i'faith, I would thou hadst more room.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Once more the gracious heavens have renewed
My wasted hopes, once more a blessed chance
Hath fetched again my spirit from the sound
And languishing despair of happiness.
A skilful Beldam with the Juice of herbs
Hath cured my face, and killed the venoms power,
And now if Pasquil live and love me still,
Heaven is bounteous to poor Katherine
Yon sups my Father, but my Ned is not there
I fear, and yet I know not what I fear.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Gallants I drink this to Ned Pasquils health.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: i'faith I will pledge him, would he had his wits.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: And I my daughter. Fill me one Cup more:
No grief so potent, but neat sparkling wine
Can conquer him: O this is Juice divine.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Would he had his wits. O what a numbing fear
Strikes a cold palsy through my trembling blood.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Virtue shall burst ope the Iron gates of Hell,
I will not be cooped up, room for Phaeton.
Lame policy how canst thou go upright ?
O Lust, stain not sweet love. Fie be not lost
Upon the surge of vulgar humours. You Idiot
Rivet my Armour, and Caparison,
A mighty Centaur, for I will run at Tilt,
And tumble down yon Giant in the dust.
Sit gentle Judges of great Radamant
Let not Proserpine rule thee. O she is dead.
Now thou art right Eacus, I appeal to thee,
Have pity on a wretches misery.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: I am quite sunk with grief, what shall we do
To get recovery of his wits again ?

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: Let Music sound, for I have often heard
It hath such sweet agreement with our souls,
That it corrects vain humours, and recalls
His straggling fancies to fair union.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Why the soul of man is naught but symphonies,
A sound of disagreeing parts, yet fair unite
By heavens hand, divine by reasons light.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Sound Music, then pray God it take effect.

div1.stage: The Musickes soundes, and Pasquils Eye is fixt vpon Catherine.

sp.speaker: Bra.Iu.
sp.l: Mark with what passion he sucks up the sweets
Of this same delicate harmonious breath.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Observe him well, methinks his eye is fixed
Upon some object that seems to attract
His very soul forth with astonishment.
Mark with what vehemence his thoughts do speak
Even in his eyes, some creature stands far off,
That hath entranced him with a pleasing sight.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Amazement, wonder, stiff astonishment,
Stare and stand gazing on this miracle,
Perfection, of what ever a human thought
Can reach with his discoursive faculties,
Thou whose sweet presence purifies my sense,
And dost create a second soul in me,
Dear Katherine the life of Pasquils hopes.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Dear Pasquil the life of Katherines hopes.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Once more let me embrace the constantest one
That ever was termed her Sex perfection.

sp.speaker: Kathe.
sp.l: Once more let me be valued worth his love,
In decking of whose soul, the graces strove.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Spite hath outspent itself, and thus at last,
We clip with joyful arm each others waist.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: O pardon me thou dread omnipotence,
I thought thou couldst not thus have blessed me.
O thou hast dewed my gray hairs with thy love,
And made my old heart sprout with fertile joy.

sp.speaker: Kathe.
sp.l: Forget dear father, that my act hath wronged
The quiet of your age.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: No more, no more, I know what thou wouldst say
Daughter, there is nothing but salvation,
Could come unto my heart more gracious
Than is the sight of my dear Katherine
Son Pasquill now, for thou shalt be my son,
What frolic gentle youth.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Is Mamon here ?

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.p: O Sir, Master. Mamon is in a City of Jury, called Bethlem, Alias plain Bedlam : the price of whips is mightily risen since his brain was pitifully overtumbled, they are so fast spent upon his shoulders.

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: O sacred heavens, how just is thy revenge ?

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Why? did he cast you in the labyrinth
Of these strange crosses?

sp.speaker: Pas.
sp.l: Yes honoured knight, which in more private place
And fitter time, I will disclose at large.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: Faith Sister, as I am your elder borne,
So will I match before or with you sure,
Young Master. Brabant?

sp.speaker: Bra.
sp.l: By this light not I.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: Honest Master. Ellis?

sp.speaker: Ellis.
sp.l: No indeed law, not I, I do not use to marry :
For even as black patches are worn,
Some for pride, some to stay the Rheum, and
Some to hide the scab, even so Iohn Ellis
Scorn her, that hath scorned him.

sp.speaker: Came.
sp.l: Virtuous Master Planet.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Errant wandering star we shall never agree.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: Master. Brabant, Master. Planet, Master. Ellis, faith I will have any.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: But nobody will have thee, this is the plague of light inconstancy.
Go Twedle, bid the Butler broach fresh wine,
Set up wax lights, and furnish new the boards,
Knock down a score of Beefs,
Invite my neighbours straight,
And make my Dressers groan with weight of meat.
Master. Ellis, pray you let us hear your high Dutch Song,
You are admired for it: Good let us hear it.

sp.speaker: El.
sp.p: I do not use to sing, and yet even as when the sky falls we shall have Larks, even so when my voice riseth, you shall have a Song.
sp.stage: He singeth, holding a Bowle of drinke in his hand.
sp.l: Give us once a drink, for an the black Bowl,
Sing gentle Butler balley moy,
For an the black bowl. Sing gentle Butler balley moy.
Give us once some drink, for an the pint Pot,
Sing gentle Butler balley moy, the pint port,
For an the black bowl. Sing gentle Butler balley moy.
Give us once a drink, for an the quart Pot,
Sing gentle Butler bally moy, the quart, the pint Pot,
For an the black bowl. Sing gentle Butler bally moy.
Give us once some drink, for an the pottle Pot,
Sing gentle Butler bally moy, the pottle, the quart, the pint pot,
For an the black bowl. Sing gentle Butler bally moy.
Give us once a drink, for an the gallan Pot,
Sing gentle Butler bally moy, the gallan, the pottle, the quart,
the pint pot, for an the black bowl.
Sing gentle Butler bally moy.
Give us once a drink for an the Firkin,
Sing gentle Butler bally moy, the Firkin, the gallan, the pottle,
the quart, the pint pot, for an the black bowl.
Sing gentle Butler bally moy.
Give us once a drink for an the Kilderkin,
Sing gentle Butler bally moy, the Kilderkin, the Firkin,
the gallan, the pottle, the quart, the pint pot,
for and the black bowl. Sing gentle Butler bally moy.
Give us once some drink for an the Barrel,
Sing gentle Butler bally moy, the Barrel, the Kilderkin,
the Firkin, the gallan, the pottle, the quart, the pint pot,
for an the black bowl. Sing gentle Butler bally moy.
Give us once some drink for an the Hogshead,
Sing gentle Butler bally moy, the Hogshead, the Barrel,
the Kilkerkin, the Firkin, the gallan, the pottle, the quart, the pint
pot, for an the black bowl. Sing gentle Butler bally moy.
Give us once a drink for an the But,
Sing gentle Butler bally moy, the But, the Hogshead, the Barrel,
the Kilderkin, the Firkin, the gallan, the pottle, the quart,
the pint pot, for an the black bowl.
Sing gentle Butler bally moy.
Give us once some drink for an the Pipe,
Sing gentle Butler bally moy, the Pipe, the But, the Hogshead,
the Barrel, the Kilderkin, the Firkin, the gallan, the pottle,
the quart, the pint pot, for an the black bowl.
Sing gentle Butler bally moy.
Give us once some drink for an the Tun,
Sing gentle Butler bally moy, the Tun, the Pipe, the But,
the Hogshead, the Barrel, the Kilderkin, the Firkin, the gallan,
the pottle, the quart, the pint pot, for an the black bowl.
Sing gentle Butler bally moy.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Well done, i'faith it was chanted merrily:
What my Gallants, never a tickling Jest
To make us swoon with mirth ere we go in?

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.l: Faith Gent. I have brewed such a strong headed Jest
Will make you drunk, and reel with laughter:
You know Monsieur Iohn fo-de-king

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Very well, he read French to my daughters.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.p: Aye to gull the Fool, have brought him to my wife, as to a loose lascivious Courtesan, she being a mere stranger to the Jest, and there some three hours ago left him: but I am sure she hath so cudgeled him with quick sharpe Jests, and so battered him with a volley of her wit, as indeed she is exceeding witty, and admirable chaste, that in my conscience he will never dare to court women more. Would to God he were returned.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: See even on your wish he is come.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Iesu preserve you sweet Metre Brabant by gor the most delicate plump Wench that ever me touch : me am your slave, your peasant ; by gor a votre service whilst I live for this.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.p: He would persuade you now that he touched her, with an immodest hand. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: Touch her, by Gor me touch her, and touch her, and me touch her, me never touch such a wench, the fine foot, the cleanest leg, the sleekest skin: and me tell the sure token, she hath the finest little wart you know where : hee by Gor me never touch such a Wench.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Pray God he have not brewed a heady Jest indeed.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.l: Why faith Gentlemen I am Cuckold, by this light I am.

sp.speaker: Moun.
sp.p: By gor me no know, you tell a me it was a Courtesan, prey you pardon me, by my troth, me teach you French to the end of the world.

sp.speaker: Pla.
sp.l: Come here is thy Cap of Maintenance, the Coronet
Of Cuckolds. Nay you shall wear it, or wear
My Rapier in your guts by heaven.
Why dost thou not well deserve to be thus used ?
Why shouldest thou take felicity to gull
Good honest souls, and in thy arrogance
And glorious ostentation of thy wit,
Think God infused all perfection
Into thy soul alone, and made the rest
For thee to laugh at? Now you Censurer
Be the ridiculous subject of our mirth.
Why Fool, the power of Creation
Is still Omnipotent, and there is no man that breathes
So valiant, learned, witty, or so wise,
But it can equal him out of the same mold.
Wherein the first was formed. Then learn proud scorn,
And honest self made Cuckold, wear the horn.

sp.speaker: Bra.Sig.
sp.l: Wear the horn ? Aye , spite of all your teethe
I will wear this Crown, and triumph in this horn.

sp.speaker: Sir Ed.
sp.l: Why faith it is valorously spoke fair Sir,
We will solemnise your Coronation
With royal pomp. Now Gentlemen prepare
A liberal spirit to entertain a Jest,
Where free light Jocund mirth shall be enthroned
With sumptuous state. Now Music beat the air,
Entrance our thoughts with your harmonious sounds,
Our Fortune laughs, and all content abounds.
